abstract.text: A data object containing information about the reasons why UIKit created the scene.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: UIKit creates scenes for many reasons. It might do so in response to a Handoff request or a request to open a URL. When there’s a specific reason for creating a scene, UIKit fills a

object with the associated data and passes it to your delegate at connection time. Use the information in this object to respond accordingly. For example, open the URLs that UIKit provides, and display their contents in the scene.
objects for you and passes them to the

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An object that represents one instance of your app’s user interface.
A data object containing information about the reasons why UIKit created the scene.
Information about the CloudKit data that’s now available to the app.
A CredentialSession event has triggered a UIKit scene creation.
The type of the pending Handoff activity.
An event, such as a gesture or exposure to a card reader’s RF field, that creates a Near-Field Communication (NFC) scene.
A person’s response to one of your app’s notifications.
The user-selected action to perform.
The bundle ID of the app that originated the request.
The URLs to open, along with metadata specifying how to open them.
Information about user activities that you can use to configure your scene’s interface.
Tells the delegate about the addition of a scene to the app.
Tells the delegate that UIKit removed a scene from your app.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
